subject: RE: [junit] Individual tests ok, problem in a suite
msgSnippet: Similar to JB s response - you haven t got some (hidden) static data somewhere that is being set (and not reset) between tests?  Periodically in some legacy
messageBody:
Similar to JB's response - you haven't got some (hidden) static data
somewhere that is being set (and not reset) between tests? Periodically
in some legacy code I get bitten by this: tests all run fine in
isolation and at package level but then when I run the whole
application's set something(s) "fail" for some unknown reason. In my
case invariably its some static data (or a rogue "singleton") that's the
root cause.



Jonathan



________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
J. B. Rainsberger
Sent: 11 May 2005 01:54
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Individual tests ok, problem in a suite



keirstead_james wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I've got a weird situation and can't figure out how to debug it.
> Perhaps someone has some advice?
>
> I have a class called HouseholdTest. If I run this test by itself,
> it's ok.
>
> I also have a class suite called AgentsTestSuite which contains the
> HouseholdTest. If I run this test, I get errors on one or two of the
> methods; i.e rerunning the test over and over again sometimes gives
> one error and sometimes two (always on the same methods). If I use
> Rerun failed tests - Failures first, the test is ok in all
> circumstances.
>
> AgentsTestSuite is inside another suite called ModelTest. Running
> this throws up errors on the same methods as above, plus another in a
> different test suite (which again is ok by itself). Rerunning failed
> tests first clears one of the methods in the HouseholdTest but that's
> it.
>
> What is going on here? I've spent quite a while debugging it but
> can't seem to figure out where the snag is. Has anyone else
> encountered something like this?

I imagine your HouseholdTest tests use some external resource (file
system, database, something). If so, then something else in your
AgentsTestSuite is putting that external resource in a state that your
HouseholdTest tests doesn't expect. Clean that up, if you can.

If that's not it, then I would need more specifics to get any further.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
